text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion specifically asks whether the response identifies that Article V(1)(e) of the New York Convention allows refusal of enforcement when an award has been set aside at the seat of arbitration (Paris). The candidate answer focuses entirely on defending enforcement against challenges based on lack of jurisdiction (Art. V(1)(c)) and due process (Art. V(1)(b)), and mentions the possibility of set-aside proceedings only in passing within the context of the *Chromalloy* precedent (which actually enforced an award annulled at the seat, contrary to the premise of V(1)(e)). The candidate answer fails to explicitly mention or analyze Article V(1)(e) as a potential ground for refusal based on the award being set aside at the seat, which is the exact focus of this criterion.", "criterion_id": "4e27ec7e-c6c3-4702-94e3-c62fdc7b481d"}
